text: the price of living in the modern world
is a feeling that we've fallen out of
touch with the natural world we long for
a lost innocence that may never have
existed but that still exerts a
significant hold on our imaginations
there's something primal and powerful
about this feeling but it's also
exceedingly complex and both the power
and the complexity are vividly on
display in Nicholas rags film walkabout

walk about concerns a teenage girl and
her younger brother who are inexplicably
abandoned by their father in the middle
of the Australian desert they are
befriended and saved by a young
Aborigine who's in the middle of his
walkabout a rite of passage in which he
must go on his own through the outback
in order to become a man wet they keep
the water good god pick up all the
regulars British there's a lot and
walkabout that anticipates the
Australian new wave of the mid in late
1970s it condemns the brutality of
Western civilization while celebrating
the nobility and vitality of native
people it's violent sexy poetic trippy
sometimes almost to the point of
self-indulgence
but it's entrancing there's no way to
watch this movie without becoming
totally absorbed and involved in a large
part of the movies appeal lies in the
beauty of its images they're really
extraordinary and this was Nicolas regs
first solo directing credit but it came
after a 10 year career as a
cinematographer and camera operator but
it's not just that the images are
artfully or expertly composed reg uses
the camera wide shots close-ups colors
and textures to create a sense of
unmediated perception as if we were
seeing the world for the very first time
we see the bond that forms among these
children which is beautiful and pure but
also tragic and destructive what you

we see that sexual desire is universal
more powerful than the cultural norms

you see that innocence is always lost
